dismissalText.commentary: Kusal Perera c Billings b Willey 73 (81b 7x4 0x6 150m) SR: 90.12

dismissalComment.html: huge heave across the line, and Billings pockets the pull! It's a long old boundary, and the man is stationed right back on the rope. Perera's valiant effort is over, and now England will be sensing a quick kill

dismissalText.commentary: Wanindu Hasaranga c Livingstone b Woakes 54 (65b 6x4 1x6 91m) SR: 83.07

dismissalComment.html: the short ball does it again for Woakes! Hasaranga takes it on, but the boundary is huge and he can't get hold of it, or keep it down. Livingstone sprints in from deep midwicket and scoops up another fine outfield catch, he took a similar one in the T20Is, and there ends a valiant innings

headshotImage.caption: Pathum Nissaka player page headshot cutout, 2021
headshotImage.longCaption: Pathum Nissaka player page headshot cutout, 2021

dismissalComment.html: pulled straight to short midwicket! Bit of a long-hop, 80mph and back of a length, and Nissanka pulls with a full extension of the arms, but can't get it over Moeen, who takes the simplest catch imaginable! A cunning ploy...

image.caption: Dasun Shanaka, player portrait
image.longCaption: Dasun Shanaka, player portrait

headshotImage.caption: Dasun Shanaka player page headshot cutout, 2021
headshotImage.longCaption: Dasun Shanaka player page headshot cutout, 2021

dismissalComment.html: absolute beauty, not far short of unplayable. This is liquid Woakes. Perfect length, angling in from over the wicket, nipping away just a touch off the seam, and finding the outside edge as Shanaka gets forward to defend. A thin outside edge, through to Bairstow, and England have a third!

dismissalComment.html: sharp take at a solitary slip! That's brilliant from Root, but also from Woakes, pushing it across the left-hander, perfect seam position punishing the hard-handed punch, and the 150-cap man springs into action, diving to his left to snaffle Woakes' fourth of the innings!

headshotImage.longCaption: Charith Asalanka, player page headshot cutout 2022

dismissalComment.html: edged and gone! Duck for Asalanka on debut. Not much of a shot, if truth be told. Back of a length, bit of bounce, and Asalanka plays away from his body with minimal foot movement, looking to punch defensively towards cover-point. Thick outside edge, and Root gobbles up the chance at slip

dismissalComment.html: skewed straight to short midwicket! Dug in, back of a length, and Fernando gets himself into a right pickle trying to work to leg. It loops up off the bat, straight to Moeen in close, and Sri Lanka lose their eighth. From 145 for 3, Sri Lanka have lost 5 for 15.

dismissalText.commentary: Ramesh Mendis lbw b Ali 1 (5b 0x4 0x6 7m) SR: 20

dismissalComment.html: crashed on the pad... a huge pause for thought and Robinson puts up the finger! Mendis reviews... there's no bat as the ball tweaks into a planted front pad, and it's clipping leg! Unlucky, had it been not out on the field it would have stayed not out. But England are deep into their day's work now

dismissalText.commentary: Dushmantha Chameera run out (Billings/Curran) 7 (15b 1x4 0x6 20m) SR: 46.66

dismissalComment.html: comedy running once again, and both batters are at the keeper's end. Throw comes in to Curran at the bowler's end, and he does the rest. Someone find the Benny Hill music. Length ball from Curran, steered to Billings at point. Chameera had no interest in the single but by the time he'd looked up, Karunaratne was stood next to him. Billings kept his composure and Curran knocked the bails off. Chameera sacrifices himself. Mickey Arthur has his head in his hands... again!

dismissalText.commentary: Praveen Jayawickrama run out (Billings) 4 (7b 1x4 0x6 11m) SR: 57.14

dismissalComment.html: run out at the bowler's end! Much better fielding, this time from Sam Billings who is a notoriously gun outfielder. Pressed into the leg side, towards mid-on, and they immediately set off for two. Billings hares in, picks up, throws at the bowler's end, and the direct hit sees Jayawickrama well short! His second brilliant run-out in as many games.

commentTextItems.html: Full toss, flogged through mid-on, that'll do it! Curran mops up the resistance to put England 1-0 up. Wonder if anyone's managed similar in the football yet...

commentPostTextItems.html: 5.43pm That's the end of that then. England make it four in a row in their white-ball campaign. From myself and Matt, and Thilak and the rest of the ESPNcricinfo team, good night, good luck if football is your thing (and especially if it isn't) and see you at The Oval!

Kusal Perera, who made a battling 73. "I am trying to back myself and do my basis, try to bat to the 40th over, 50 would have been great. But two more games to go. Hasaranga did a good job for the team, we got a partnership but not enough for the team. It's a team game, we have to get together to get a good score."

Eoin Morgan "Delighted, good lengths, adapting to conditions, good lengths, cross-seam, full credit to the bowling unit, they really did fire. The lead bowlers at mid-off, mid-on, good communication with the three of us and the keeper is crucial.

On Root: "he's one of the best in the world, in most situations. Notable in training how easy he finds things, never seems to struggle. I think you can't rule Joe out [of T20 World Cup] the role he played in 2016 was a big part in getting us to the final, and the knock he played in the final was outstanding." So there you go.

The Player of the Match is Chris Woakes: "I think opening the bowling, a big part of the job is assessing conditions and communicating. Taking wickets stems the run-flow but trying to be as accurate as possible. Don't want to give any freebies, width goes to the boundary, try not to leave the stumps, find the length that hits the bails until the batsman tries something different. My rhythm wasn't too bad, a bit short in first two overs, couple of games for Warks, hit my straps well."
5.36pm Nothing else going on elsewhere, is there?

5.30pm So, it wasn't pretty but it was mighty effective. Joe Root, in his 150th ODI, restates his value as England's barometer in the middle order. No rush to get the runs, so he took no rush at all, but still ticked along at a 90-odd strike rate, 79 not out from 87 balls. And he's got 6000 runs in the format too.

Chris Woakes played a blinder too with the ball - the stunning figures of 4 for 18 in ten overs, with five maidens - four of them in the Powerplay. And Jonny Bairstow was outstanding in reply before getting out when gloriously set. No-one else made it look so easy all day. And a note too for Dushmantha Chameera, four wickets last week, three more today. He was a constant menace in an innings where wickets were Sri Lanka's only currency. And what might have happened if Moeen Ali had been caught first ball?

George Macphers: "Thank god that's over. It's shouldn't be that hard to chase down a score of 185. Hopefully the next ODI will be a lot better than this one." You are a terrible pampered human. I rather enjoyed seeing a bit of a tussle!

commentTextItems.html: full length, into the pads, flicked in front of square, scores are level

commentPostTextItems.html: Abhijato: "Sri Lanka have really exceeded expectations here, as depressing as that might sound - I suspect the rest of the series isn't going to be the cakewalk England thought it would be if the Lankans can settle into their roles." Indeed. Their bowlers need their batters to give them something to work with. Nearly managed it today!

commentTextItems.html: dipping from round the wicket, blocked out to point
flashed down to third man, England chipping away as Curran throws his bat outside off stump

commentPostTextItems.html: WrongTeam: "Root showing his value, again, but MoM for Woakes methinks" That feels fair to me

commentTextItems.html: fenced off the pads, and into the leg side
banged in short, ducked

commentPostTextItems.html: Racheed: "The one bright spark to come from Sri Lanka's disastrous recent form is Chameera. He's really developed nicely, is sharp, and can lead that pace attack for the future. " So true. So long as they don't snap his willowy frame, they've found themselves a proper competitor

commentTextItems.html: round the wicket, tailing into the toes, blocked to the off-side
full toss, patted into the covers
swings into the pull, down to backward square. England are a boundary away
climbs into the drive, and the intent burgles him a boundary, off a fat edge through the vacant slip. He'll take that, even if he was aiming about 100 degrees further into the covers
flicked off the hip to backward square

commentPostTextItems.html: George Macphers: "What a poor reply from England. Chasing 180 and now 6 wickets down against a inconsistent Sri Lanka bowling attack. Not good advertisement for cricket. Where is the England team that were able to dominate matches?" George, George, even on hand with the hottest of takes. They are about to win with approximately 16 overs to spare. Not an appalling day's work when you look at it like that

commentTextItems.html: Curran keeps the strike with a nudge into the gap. England are nearly there

A thin outside edge, through to Bairstow, and England have a third!

dismissalText.commentary: Dushmantha Chameera run out (Billings/Curran) 7 (15b 1x4 0x6 20m) SR: 46.66

dismissalComment.html: comedy running once again, and both batters are at the keeper's end. Throw comes in to Curran at the bowler's end, and he does the rest. Someone find the Benny Hill music. Length ball from Curran, steered to Billings at point. Chameera had no interest in the single but by the time he'd looked up, Karunaratne was stood next to him. Billings kept his composure and Curran knocked the bails off. Chameera sacrifices himself. Mickey Arthur has his head in his hands... again!

dismissalText.commentary: Praveen Jayawickrama run out (Billings) 4 (7b 1x4 0x6 11m) SR: 57.14

dismissalComment.html: run out at the bowler's end! Much better fielding, this time from Sam Billings who is a notoriously gun outfielder. Pressed into the leg side, towards mid-on, and they immediately set off for two. Billings hares in, picks up, throws at the bowler's end, and the direct hit sees Jayawickrama well short! His second brilliant run-out in as many games.
